reviewText:
My karting days go way back to the godfather of karting games Super Mario Kart on the SNES. Having played the majority of clones and spin off games since, it'd be fair to say I'm in a decent position to give a valued and trusted opinion.

Aside from perhaps Speed Freaks on the PS1, this is hands down the best Mart Kart clone available today. The added flight and boat modes do not take away the fun or karting aspects of the game and really do enhance the experience. I definately recommend this to anyone who enjoys karting games or arcade style racing in general.

Well worth the £14 this game is currently listed as. If your lucky enough to catch it on Steam sale, grab it!

reviewText: Sonic & Sega All-Stars Racing Transformed is, aside from the lengthy name, possibly the most fun I've had in any racing game so far, and despite it being at least somewhat inspired by Mario Kart it still feels original. From what I've seen so far the community is extremely friendly which is always nice to see and just under 2 years later there are groups still activley playing this game every day. reviewText: Racing games have been a huge genre in the gaming industry, most racing games are really popular, like Mario Kart, Forza, etc., and there are really bad ones like Big Rigs Over the Road Racing. Sega's Sonic the Hedgehog in the late 90's made their own spinoff Sonic Racing games, but the first one's were Sonic R, and Sonic Drift, these two games were considered by many to be terrible. then during the time of the PS2, Sega released a new franchise called Sega Superstars
date:
this game was really mediocre because it was one of the few games on the system to use the Playstation Eye, but it registered poorly, so the game was not good. Sega decided to step back into racing in 2006, with Sonic Riders, released for Gamecube, Xbox, PS2, and PC, this game was much better than Sonic R and Drift, it was different because unlike most racing games, this racing game used hoverboards, and a sequel was released in 2008.

2 years after Sonic Riders Zero Gravity, Sega decided to revive Sega Superstars with a tennis game before 2010, and in 2010, we got Sonic and Sega All Stars Racing. This racing game released for Xbox 360, PS3, Wii, DS, and PC, recevied really positive reviews. So much that it could start comparing to Mario Kart.

2 short years after Sonic and Sega All Stars Racing, we got the game were talking about today... Sonic and All Stars Racing Transformed. Released for Xbox 360, PS3, Wii U, PC, 3DS, PSVita, and mobile devices. So, is this a good racing game? Yes. The graphics on PC are stunning, especially in Max Settings, running 60fps, the colors are bright and colorful, and the small blur affects make the game a bit more intense. The gameplay plays like its original, Steer, Accelerate, Drift to charge up a mini turbo, and do tricks in mid air, which is replaced by flicking the right control stick in a specific direction, (I'm assuming you have a controller) the trick system is a lot simpler and quicker than the original.

The main gimic of this game is the ability to transform your kart into a boat, or plane, in boat form, you can ride the waves and  perform tricks by jumping off waves, specifically big ones, and even ride on hot lava, literally. In plane form, you can fly around in the air, while doing barrel rolls to dodge mid air obstacles, such as giant dinosaurs, construction areas, magic bookshelves, and flying aircrafts.

The game has a wide variety of modes, race, grand prix, time attack, world tour, battle mode, and even online, and the game has 20 race tracks and a large selection of Sega characters, and I mean it. You can even level up your favorite character and unlock mods for your character to customize their stats! So you can use your favorite character and still have good stats! Also, there are a handfull of collectable stickers and badges to put on your ID card.

The soundtrack in this game is really good, with many remixes, but voice clips are resused from past Sega games. But it is still nice to listen to to say the least.

If I had to give a final verdict on the game, I would say if Sega's goal was to make a racing game that uses features from many other Sega franchises, and bundle it all into one epic racing game, than they accomplished that very well, the gameplay is good, the soundtrack is epic, the online is fun, the selection of characters is great, and the graphics are beautiful to look at on the PC, but not so much on the Console versions of the game. This is a fantastic racing game that will keep you playing for hours, and has really fun online, I can safely say that this is one of the best racing games out there. I score this game with a 9/10. $20 is a good price, but in the steam sales, $5 is ridiculous, you better buy this in the sales! I reccomend this to any racing fan out there!

reviewText:
B.D. Joe & All-Stars Racing Transformed is wonderfully arcadey, bright, colorful, runs silky-smooth and is generally a truckload (or boatload (or planeload)) of fun to play. It's the best racing game I've played in a long time.

+ Colors! Cheer!
+ Arcadey
+ Challenging
+ Makes very effective use of Wii-tier models & textures - Looks great and runs very nicely
+ I've only played a couple of the games represented in this game for a few minutes apiece and I still love almost all of the characters (Amigo)
+ Good soundtrack
+ Lag shouldn't effect your movement too much online, with one major exception...

- Vehicle-on-vehicle collisions online. Good God, the vehicle-on-vehicle collisions online. Some games try to handle physics but it still doesn't work too good. This game just doesn't handle physics. They don't even work for the host player. Works okay offline, though.
- S-Class AI tends to be a bag of ♥♥♥♥♥
- There is a ramp on Burning Depths that you can crash into while trying to go over it, and you will lose if this happens. This is dumb.


Verdict: I love it.

9/10

reviewText:
Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed excels in almost every aspect of the kart racing genre. The drifting feels natural, the tracks are varied, the weapons are interesting and fair, and the boosting mechanics are great fun to exploit. Where it suffers somewhat is in the character selection - Sonic and company are great, but the rest of the roster is padded with significantly less recognizable entries. Overall a well polished kart racer.

The games’ mechanics are well thought-out. Everything works well together:
* Boosts can be gained from drifting, boost pads, and doing tricks while in mid air. You are rewarded for chaining different types of boosts together, which makes you always on the lookout for trick/drift opportunities.
* Weapons are powerful, but they always leave the targeted player with some recourse to deal with them. All automatically tracking weapons can be boosted away from if timed correctly, and nearly all other weapons can be dodged in some way.
* Tracks are dynamic and sometimes will change from lap to lap. Tracks generally will have different paths to choose from, each offering either extra boosts, extra trick jumps/drifts, or extra weapon pickups.

Kart racing games are often a party game, and this is where Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed might fall short for you. The fact is most people are familiar with Mario Kart. Plumbers, princesses and shells are recognizable to the casual gamer and that familiarity can make a game much easier to get in to. Sonic Racing's monkeys, fireworks and pufferfish aren't as familiar to people, and until a player gets a feel for how the world and the weapons work the well-crafted mechanics will be lost on them.

Still, the bottom line is that it feels good to drive your boat/plane/car around; flipping, drifting, boosting and shooting your way to victory. Recommended.

reviewText:
This game is awesome, but if you hear me playing you may well think it's terrible because it sure makes me hurl a lot of abuse at the screen! Make no mistake, this game is HARD!! You can choose your difficulty for every race, but you need stars to unlock things. I have had no problems unlocking things, but I start out on medium and then try for hard (I think I cleared about 2/3 on hard and left the rest on medium so far). If you're more of an easy-maybe-trying-for-medium kind of player, you may end up stuck or frustrated that you can't unlock additional characters.

If you do decide to take the plunge, be sure to visit the steam forum page for this game and take a look at the top pinned topic for some awesome tips. You really need to learn how to boost-start and drift to start getting anywhere in the game for instance.

The weapons are imaginative and they're not TOO disruptive (there are no I win" weapons)

reviewText: Good Kart Racing Game...actually GREAT Kart Racing Game. I myself was raised on Nintendo and only later in life learned about Sonic the Hedgehog and friends. Most of the characters and scenes in this game I am completely oblivious to, but what I am not oblivious to is that I know a good kart racer when I play one. The mechanics in this game remind me of Diddy Kong Racing with the different dimensions the race happens in except you switch midrace. Simply a great game for the kart racing fan in you even if you werent big on the SEGA franchises.\n\nSolid Kart Racer 8 out of 10

reviewText:
Got this from the humble Sega bundle recently, originally for (hoping for, and later on became true) Sonic Generations. I have always liked racing games in general and the Mario Kart series. I went into this game not expecting much... boy was I wrong.

Being honest, at first, I couldn't see how this game was good despite hearing that it was. The drifting felt strange as a Mario Kart player. The speed boosts obtained didn't seem very significant. I couldn't beat the 2nd hardest difficulty for my first session or so in the game... and this was early on in the world tour" mode.

Then
date: I tried time attack for the first time. I was initially disappointed by how you were only able to do one of the three laps in a normal race; I wanted to run the full 3 laps. However
hoursPlayed: I've come to accept it as okay.\n\nAnyway
voteText: I saw one of the top ghosts going unbelievably fast (to this very moment

votesTotal: I beat that
votesFunny: and... an expert ghost comes out. While not nearly as fast as the top lap times
commentsCount: I could not keep up.\n\nThe game had more things for me to learn than I thought. On top of track layout
column16: there are things like: Switching drift direction mid-chain. Air tricks. Transform boosts. Utilizing the small hops in the terrain/water as a car/boat for an extra trick
column17: while drifting. Risk boosts in a plane. Boost levels beyond the stated 3 from drifting. Using a boost/drift boost to evade the remote control item. Holding drifts or not drifting on certain parts of tracks for more speed than if I let go of a boost. Being able to drift while not holding the accelerator to make tighter turns. Those are the things I learned in my 28 hours according to steam

It's a shame they even brought back 4 old tracks (20 total) from the previous iteration of this game where there's only a car section. Those are by far my least favorite tracks

maximizing your speed in each is great fun. They are all beautiful and fairly colorful. I want more; double that. Sumo entertainment (makers of this game) can make great tracks.

reviewText:
Fun (but often frustrating) racing game. There's your traditional racing mode (more on that below), and the standard arena modes you'd find in most modern racing games, plus capture the flag.

The story mode, involving unlocking tracks via gated progression based off of how well you perform in previous races, can be enormously frustrating at times. There are four difficulty settings for each track: Easy, Medium, Hard, and Expert (which only unlocks after you've beaten the tracks on an easier difficulty first) and each present their own spin on AI. Easy is pretty much a cakewalk, and anyone familiar with the controls should be able to fly through each race. The others, though, are a different story.

The AI cheats in this game. A LOT. They are completely shameless about it. Every race, you start dead last in 10th place far behind everyone else, and half of the AI get boost starts on top of that. If you manage to overcome that massive handicap, you'll also have to deal with conspiring AI (they will always opt to fire their skills at you instead of other AI if possible), immediate & flawless reaction times, and to top it all off, one bot each race will basically be Wonder Woman. They're substantially harder, faster, better, stronger than all the other bots.

Beating this game on Hard boils down to first managing to fly past the other 8 bots without any of them ever getting a good ability hit on you (if you do, you might as well restart the race) and then duking it out with the Alpha bot of the pack and hope that you get All Star before he/she does.

I haven't even tried to get past the first race of the first zone on Expert -- the bots will utilize every map exploit, corner trick, and power-up to completely ♥♥♥♥ you over. I'm sticking to my theory that this is a difficulty reserved for the sole purpose of derisively taunting your racing skills.

Overall impressions: It might be worth a pickup at $20 if you enjoy racing games. At $5, it's probably worth getting just for the menagerie of characters. Just be prepared for your robot overlords.

reviewText:
This is what all Sonic racers should have been. It beats Mario Kart in:
-Art
-Characters
-Speed
-Tracks
-Skill
-Music

Things I don't like:
- Inability to turn off the menu music but keep the stages';
- The annoying announcer telling you what to do every 30 seconds;
- Unstable netcode (sometimes);
- Unnecessarily long wait times;
- Extremely loud splash screen.

This didn't keep me from grossing 200+ hours, though. Online play is awesome. I highly recommend watching videos of the pros to hone in your racing skills.

reviewText: Best Mario Kart ever!

reviewText:
You might take one look at Sonic & ALL-Stars Racing Transformed and see it as a Mario Kart knock off. While they are similar, I would say this game borrows more elements from Diddy Kong Racing on the N64. Both these games feature hovercrafts, airplanes, and karts. The difference with this title is that the vehicles transform between all of these within each course. And might I add that the courses look spectacular! Not only that, but they are actually really well designed. Each course is filled with nods of nostalgia if you ever owned a Master System, Genesis, Saturn, Dreamcast, or any Sega game. The music is brilliantly catchy consisting of remixed SEGA tunes from previous catalogs. It's obviously not Mario Kart and lacks the eggshells, invincibility stars, The Mushroom Kingdom, etc. This is SEGA so it's all Sonic galore. Thankfully, this game isn't based soley on characters from the Sonic universe and most of the disliked characters from the series are NOT included. In return, this game mixes characters from other Sega games such as NiGHTs, Alex Kidd, and Beat from Jet Set Radio. Most of the included characters aren't even popular Sega characters, but the fact they have been included is total fan service. Surprisingly, this game is actually fun and REALLY REALLY fast. It's both addictive and challenging with tons of unlockables. And it sports online play with voice communication! Sadly, most will compare this to Mario Kart and shove it off as knock off.
The reality is that Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed actually gives Mario Kart a run for it's money. Thus, it's sort of like picking between apples and oranges and in this case, it just becomes a Sega does what NintenDONT. (Just had to say it.)

In conclusion, this is one of the best Sega games I've played in recent years. Go figure it was made by Sumo Digital, a second party studio outside of SEGA. In theory, maybe Sega should hire them more often. Anyway, despite the brilliance of this kart racer it does have a few flaws. It certainly lacks that Nintendo polish you see in the Mario Kart series. There are a couple of nasty bugs (mostly in online mode) that do appear out of no where. A patch could really do this game well. Other than that, I'd say it's almost comparable to Mario Kart, maybe some aspects even better than Mario Kart. This game is a perfect solution for those who don't own a Nintendo Platform, but are desperately craving a kart racer, and a good one at that! If you own a Wii U, this is the game you bought while you waited for Mario Kart 8. Some have even argued that Nintendo should have borrowed some elements from Transformed. Transformed is better than nothing, but it's even better if you are a fan of Sega and familar with their back catalog of games.

In short, it's Diddy Kong Racing on steroids, but with Sonic and Sega characters instead. It even has a couple of monkeys from the Super Monkey ball games...that's close enough to Diddy. Don't be fooled by Sega's mediocrity of the past. This game belongs in the top 5 kart racers list. Right up there Crash Team Racing, Diddy Kong Racing, and Mario Kart.

OVERALL:

+ Good visuals, catchy tunes, fun gameplay
-  A few nasty bugs
-  Hovercraft can be hard to control. (No different to DKR on N64)

I should also mention that this is a perfect port with no problems like many other games and any gamepad is compatable (no pressure to buy the most expensive gamepad). This will give maany hours of fun and I recommend getting a four-pack whenever you can.

reviewText: Easily one of, if not the best, kart racers I've ever played. The game is a huge love letter to Sega and its various franchises, with characters and stages from games like Jet Set Radio, Space Channel 5, Skies of Arcadia, and many more. Even if you don't have any love for Sega, though, it's still worth picking this game up. The tracks are all huge and well-designed, with each lap changing the course in some way. The transformation gimmick works out really well and makes the tracks that much more interesting. It's also incredibly well balanced. All of the racers feel unique enough for you to find somebody you like, and none of the items are overly dickish. They're all dodgeable, and the game rewards you for dealing with them effectively. The only close equivalent to the blue shell is 100% dodgeable, and in fact is easy to dodge. The game is just overall an incredibly fun and enjoyable experience, and it's super well optimized for PC. It's worth basically whatever price people ask for it.\n\nI cannot recommend this game enough. If you like Kart racers and/or Sega at all, you owe it to yourself to try this amazing game.

reviewText:
This game is a really good competitor to Mario Kart. The game's got great music, cool levels, nice graphics and nice gameplay. Don't be afraid by the game's title, this is not a Sonic game at all. The PC version is a very good looking port and it runs great for most computers.

Before you ask, yes, you should buy it. This game has become my favorite racing game, and that's saying something. I recommend the PC version because it's much cheaper and overall it's a much smoother experience. I got this game for my Wii U and the 30 FPS cap is not that satisfying.

I give this game a score of 5/5. Buy it if you like Mario Kart!

reviewText: It's probably one of the better arcade racers I've played in recent years. I should get to playing it more but I have to be in the right kind of mood to want this kind of game. The game itself is easy to pick up and play but challenging to master. I'd recommend this over the various Mario Kart racers thanks to the competitive aspect that lies somewhat hidden beneath the surface. Not all of the tracks are perfect but most of them are easy on the eyes and varied in a way that one track can have multiple environments" thanks to the different vehicle modes of going from car to airplane to boat. This is my favorite game released from SEGA since Sonic Generations.\n\nThe learning curve is very good going from lower difficulties up to harder ones and earning those medals prolongs replay ability if you're into that sort of collecting. 10 player online racing also insures that when you're tired of predictability in the racing AI you'll have slightly more unpredictable opponents to go up against. I can't speak from personal experience on that aspect because I've played the game so little and have no confidence in doing well against live opponents. It's like what my old pal Han said
recommended: good against remotes is one thing. Good against the living? That's something else." However
hoursPlayed:
I hear numerous reports that the online does work well with only minor latency issues and almost no disconnects. I would like to note that it may be harder to find as many opponents to race on the PC version with the exception of occasional sales that pop up like right now for example.

I've heard some say it was ported badly or botched somehow. I have to be honest here. I'm not easily impressed by music in most modern games. Usually we end up with some orchestral pieces or stuff that just sounds very unfitting to a video game soundtrack if that make sense. There was a time when you heard video game music and it was instantly recognizable as such mostly because of limitations of the sound chip included in a console/pc engine. For instance

reviewText:
This is a game that I wish more of my friends played. Imagine Mario Kart, but faster, and with items that are more fair.

Every item launched at you has a counter-play. The maps are well designed, the drifting is fun. Its a solid racing game that gives MK a run for its money.

My only gripe is the boat segments. They're still fun, but less so than the rest of the race. Regardless of who you're playing as, the boat can be a pain to control due to the random air-time you get with the ebb and flow of waves.

reviewText: Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed (SART) is a sequel to Sonic & Sega All-Stars Racing (SSAR), an arcade kart racing game that includes many characters and tracks from Sega titles, this one made by Sumo and released on PC in 2013. So yep, racing around competively, drifting and picking up random weapons to use on opponents.\nIt also got Xbox 360, PS3, WiiU, PSVita and 3DS versions as far as I am aware. And PC version actually got a bunch of exclusive characters (and exclusive DLC), like General Winter. Other versions weren't strangers to cameos from non-Sega franchises either. Though the only ones you miss are Avatar-using racers from Xbox 360 and WiiU. So be happy, you probably got the best version.\nIt also had a bonus edition" version for consoles which included Metal Sonic
date: OutRun stage and bonus stickers. It then became the first DLC.\n\nMultiplayer seems to be slightly alive. It's hard to say without server browser

reviewText: This is such a unique racing experience with some pretty awesome characters. It is very fast paced, and doesn't contain just straight races throughout the campaign. The campaign is filled with other types of races and time trial-type races, which make the game more interesting. The tracks are amazing, changing their structure after each lap. The transformation aspect of this game is very unique and pulled off very well. This is a great racing game.

reviewText: Really fun game. The race types are dynamic, from vs. battles to checkpoint eliminatation matches, Sonic all star transformed will keep you playing for a while. I bought this game for my son and originally I thought it was going to be way too easy of a racer for me, but it turned out that it was a pretty good challenge for both of us to beat the matches on meduim diffuculty to unlock the new characters. The roster of characters are from a variety of different games and movies, which makes it even more fun for my kids to play as these racing heroes. I recommend this game for anyone that likes the battle racing style.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: It's probably one of the better arcade racers I've played in recent years. I should get to playing it more but I have to be in the right kind of mood to want this kind of game. The game itself is easy to pick up and play but challenging to master. I'd recommend this over the various Mario Kart racers thanks to the competitive aspect that lies somewhat hidden beneath the surface. Not all of the tracks are perfect but most of them are easy on the eyes and varied in a way that one track can have multiple environments" thanks to the different vehicle modes of going from car to airplane to boat. This is my favorite game released from SEGA since Sonic Generations.\n\nThe learning curve is very good going from lower difficulties up to harder ones and earning those medals prolongs replay ability if you're into that sort of collecting. 10 player online racing also insures that when you're tired of predictability in the racing AI you'll have slightly more unpredictable opponents to go up against. I can't speak from personal experience on that aspect because I've played the game so little and have no confidence in doing well against live opponents. It's like what my old pal Han said
recommended: good against remotes is one thing. Good against the living? That's something else." However
hoursPlayed:
I hear numerous reports that the online does work well with only minor latency issues and almost no disconnects. I would like to note that it may be harder to find as many opponents to race on the PC version with the exception of occasional sales that pop up like right now for example.

I've heard some say it was ported badly or botched somehow. I never once experienced any issues with this game regarding graphical or control issues though I do use a Sixaxis controller and cannot speak for racing with mouse + keyboard. From my experience you're just asking for trouble when you play racing or fighting games without a gamepad but that's my opinion. It's one of the most stable games I've played in regards to alt+tabbing in and out of with no issues though results may vary depending on your OS.

reviewText:
This is a game that I wish more of my friends played. Imagine Mario Kart, but faster, and with items that are more fair.

Every item launched at you has a counter-play. The maps are well designed, the drifting is fun. Its a solid racing game that gives MK a run for its money.

My only gripe is the boat segments. They're still fun, but less so than the rest of the race. Regardless of who you're playing as, the boat can be a pain to control due to the random air-time you get with the ebb and flow of waves.

reviewText: If you had told me, Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed will be the best Mario Kart game ever made
date: before release, I would have called you a liar and a fraud. But, you'd've been right. Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is pretty much the best kart racer on PC, if not ever. It's very much like Mario Kart with a mix of Diddy Kong Racing in there for good measure, but it seems to be built on a staple of actual skill-based racing. Unlike some of its competing series, it is possibly to win on sheer capability alone, instead of luck (and peer misfortune). Combined with a slick sense of speed and a charmingly diverse roster of Sega all-stars
recommended: it comes out as one of the bigger advances in kart racing since the genre's conception.

reviewText:
This game is a really good competitor to Mario Kart. The game's got great music, cool levels, nice graphics and nice gameplay. Don't be afraid by the game's title, this is not a Sonic game at all. The PC version is a very good looking port and it runs great for most computers.

Before you ask, yes, you should buy it. This game has become my favorite racing game, and that's saying something. I recommend the PC version because it's much cheaper and overall it's a much smoother experience. I got this game for my Wii U and the 30 FPS cap is not that satisfying.

I give this game a score of 5/5. Buy it if you like Mario Kart!

reviewText:
This is a game that I wish more of my friends played. Imagine Mario Kart, but faster, and with items that are more fair.

Every item launched at you has a counter-play. The maps are well designed, the drifting is fun. Its a solid racing game that gives MK a run for its money.

My only gripe is the boat segments. They're still fun, but less so than the rest of the race. Regardless of who you're playing as, the boat can be a pain to control due to the random air-time you get with the ebb and flow of waves.

reviewText: It's probably one of the better arcade racers I've played in recent years. I should get to playing it more but I have to be in the right kind of mood to want this kind of game. The game itself is easy to pick up and play but challenging to master. I'd recommend this over the various Mario Kart racers thanks to the competitive aspect that lies somewhat hidden beneath the surface. Not all of the tracks are perfect but most of them are easy on the eyes and varied in a way that one track can have multiple environments" thanks to the different vehicle modes of going from car to airplane to boat. This is my favorite game released from SEGA since Sonic Generations.\n\nThe learning curve is very good going from lower difficulties up to harder ones and earning those medals prolongs replay ability if you're into that sort of collecting. 10 player online racing also insures that when you're tired of predictability in the racing AI you'll have slightly more unpredictable opponents to go up against. I can't speak from personal experience on that aspect because I've played the game so little and have no confidence in doing well against live opponents. It's like what my old pal Han said
recommended: good against remotes is one thing. Good against the living? That's something else." However
hoursPlayed:
I hear numerous reports that the online does work well with only minor latency issues and almost no disconnects. I would like to note that it may be harder to find as many opponents to race on the PC version with the exception of occasional sales that pop up like right now for example.

I've heard some say it was ported badly or botched somehow. I never once experienced any issues with this game regarding graphical or control issues though I do use a Sixaxis controller and cannot speak for racing with mouse + keyboard. From my experience you're just asking for trouble when you play racing or fighting games without a gamepad but that's my opinion. It's one of the most stable games I've played in regards to alt+tabbing in and out of with no issues though results may vary depending on your OS.

WARNING: The following huge paragraph is basically me attempting to explain and justify why I prefer video game music that sounds "video game in nature". Feel free to skip to the paragraph below it if you don't want to read a bunch of my most likely incoherent thoughts.

I have to be honest here. I'm not easily impressed by music in most modern games. Usually we end up with some orchestral pieces or stuff that just sounds very unfitting to a video game soundtrack if that make sense. There was a time when you heard video game music and it was instantly recognizable as such mostly because of limitations of the sound chip included in a console/pc engine. For instance
voteText: if you never played Mario Galaxy and then listened to most of the OST you would probably assume it was just a piece made by some contemporary orchestra. So I think what SEGA does right in their Sonic games is they include music that sounds very true to what a video game soundtrack used to sound like
helpfulPercent: except it has been updated with present day technology using instruments and other more advanced techniques and sounds they couldn't have use in the past due to the limitations I mentioned before. I want to re-implore you all that I am in no way suggesting that video game music should never be orchestral or push the limit on what you can use in a video game

votesFunny: I know that any music in a video game is automatically "video game music" and therefore I can't deny any music used in any video game

reviewText:
9.8/10

This is probably one of the best Arcade Kart Racers of all time, and my second favorite behind Crash Team Racing (for nostalgia's sake)

This game feels like a cross between Mario Kart and Jak-X with a bit of Star Fox 64 thrown in for good measure, the controls are incredibly snappy and drifting is smoother than a cashmere codpiece. I was worried that much like mario kart, the challenge of the game would dissapate once you have gotten quite proficient at it, but I was pleasently surprised to find that a fourth difficulty is introduced once you get far enough into the game.
The Transforming feature of this game I initially assumed to be a gimmick, but in actuality It forms an integral part of what makes this game great; the speedboat style parts have realistic water physics (not to mention that the water looks great too), the flight sections of tracks are well designed so that you dont get lost and the flight physics do not take days to figure out (in fact I picked them up almost instantly [after a little oh the vertical is reversed moment]) unlike some games such as battlefield.

The Variety of different game types is pleasant; race, battle race, battle arena, etc. however the time trial style mini games in the world tour such as drift challange and traffic attack (which are good fun) cannot be played on all of the tracks.
Four of the 21 tracks in the game are direct ports from the previous game, they are fairly good tracks so I can overlook this, one of these is a paid DLC that comes with metal sonic. Honestly I feel this DLC should have been free, but compared to the other DLCs which are literally just extra characters it makes some sense. So completionists beware, if you really want to get every unlock in the game you will need to spend just under $5.00 extra to get those karts.

The Graphics in this game; while its not a super duper high-end eye-gasm inducing system-melting dx11 masterpiece, the visuals are very pleasing, it is seamless and themed well, at times you may see a couple of low-res textures or low-polycount models in the backround, reminding you that this is a console port but nothing that takes away from the playing experience.

Oh, Yeah thats right, this is a console port! and before you turn tail and run sceaming to your copy of Crisis 3 and proceeding to clutch it while shivering in the corner; It is a wonderfully optimised port, solid 60fps and absolutley no stuttering, input lag or any other issues often asscosiated with console ports (cough.. cough... Trials Fusion).
SEGA have been doing a lot of great ports of late, good job you show 'em how its done!

I did own the previous game; Sonic & Sega All Stars Racing on Wii briefly, it was laggy, difficult to control and not at all fun to play, but I suppose thats just down to motion control and >30fps that you get with a wii, but Mario Kart Wii played much better than that, so Idk. The point i'm trying to make is that before purchasing All-Stars Transformed I was highly skeptical of it being any good, and well I guess I couldn't have been more wrong.

(Nearly done don't worry, It's a miracle you are still reading now to be fair).

If you enjoy Fast Paced Kart Action or just want something more exciting than you average Mario Kart game, I would definately Recommend you buy this game, It is worth the full price on store but if you dont want to shell out, then wait for it to go on sale, I nabbed it for Half Price.

Now a Couple of Warnings:
- Use a 360 controller, the game is perfectly playable on the keyboard but if you dont have n-key rollover you are gonna run into a couple of problems and inevitable frustration.
- The Config menu will not launch from steam (at least for me), you need to go to the game directory and set Launcher.exe to run in compatibility mode for XP sp-3.
- The Multiplayer Servers are empty, or at least really quiet, the game is fine with out it, but some acheivement and stickers require you to win online races, so again completionists beware.

Now buy it and race me online so I can beat you.
I'm not joking,

Did you buy it yet?

Why are you still reading this? BUY THIS GAME

reviewText:
Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed excels in almost every aspect of the kart racing genre. The drifting feels natural, the tracks are varied, the weapons are interesting and fair, and the boosting mechanics are great fun to exploit. Where it suffers somewhat is in the character selection - Sonic and company are great, but the rest of the roster is padded with significantly less recognizable entries. Overall a well polished kart racer.

The games’ mechanics are well thought-out. Everything works well together:
* Boosts can be gained from drifting, boost pads, and doing tricks while in mid air. You are rewarded for chaining different types of boosts together, which makes you always on the lookout for trick/drift opportunities.
* Weapons are powerful, but they always leave the targeted player with some recourse to deal with them. All automatically tracking weapons can be boosted away from if timed correctly, and nearly all other weapons can be dodged in some way.
* Tracks are dynamic and sometimes will change from lap to lap. Tracks generally will have different paths to choose from, each offering either extra boosts, extra trick jumps/drifts, or extra weapon pickups.

Kart racing games are often a party game, and this is where Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed might fall short for you. The fact is most people are familiar with Mario Kart. Plumbers, princesses and shells are recognizable to the casual gamer and that familiarity can make a game much easier to get in to. Sonic Racing's monkeys, fireworks and pufferfish aren't as familiar to people, and until a player gets a feel for how the world and the weapons work the well-crafted mechanics will be lost on them.

Still, the bottom line is that it feels good to drive your boat/plane/car around; flipping, drifting, boosting and shooting your way to victory. Recommended.

reviewText:
Picked this up at a bargin under £5. I grew up playing the old Kart games especially on n64 so I was hoping this was a similar experience. Heard bad things about the original but this transformed version feels very complete. A strong Career mode with loads of unlockable characters. tracks and secrets. A very very high skill ceiling; the hard and expert difficulties are incredibly challenging and demand you master all the little tips and tricks you will discover while playing. The online community will eat you alive if you drop into matchmaking on first play. The game gives you incentive to unlock mods for your characters car as the more you use a certain racer the more mods you can use for that character. Racing, Battle mode, 1v1 elimination races, bonus style racing events (booster mode, rings and traffic mode are a nice take on the checkpoint style racing to mix things up)
It has ran smooth for me at 60fps on highest settings, some really inventive tracks that nod back to mega drive/saturn/dreamcast days. (The house of the dead was my particular favourite.)
It's pretty cheap and got a lot of replayability if you don't chuck the pad out of the window for some dirty scamp pipping you to a podium position with a well placed firework missile. Fuming.
Enjoyed this one.

reviewText:
Got this game for my kids and I'm having as much fun as they are.  This is Mario Kart on some serious steroids.   Pure arcade racing in some pretty imaginative environments.  The PC port has the usual interface hiccups - but the in game action is perfect.  Everything looks crisp and the action is fast.  I do play this title with a controller - as with most racing games this benefit from analog triggers.

I had this game for the Wii U - and decided not to keep that console.  Once I saw the PC port, I knew I had to get it.  It was worth the $30 they originally charged for the game.  It was a complete steal at $5.

reviewText:
Definitely one of the most amusing and amazing racing games I have seen in some time.

Playing as one of many SEGA characters (or guests such as the TF2 Crew and Ralph), you take to a highly detailed and very fluid racetrack and race your opponents to the finish. The tracks transform and give way to water or open skies, and your vehicle will transform between car/boat/plane to adjust to the changes.

I would say the positive points of this game come from the smoothness of the racing experience, and the rewarding feeling that comes from mastering a race course or passing a particular challenge. The campaign mode tests your abilities in race types varying from normal Races to Drift Challenges, Traffic Attacks to Tank Pursuits. Each racer may earn experience/levels, which lets you modify a racer to specialize in Speed, Acceleration, Handling, Boost, or a well-Balanced version of the stats they would normally use.

The only drawbacks: the difficulty curve rises sharply for each new difficulty level, and the AI-controlled racers don't mess around at all, especially on Hard/Expert difficulty; it may be a rough ride regardless of player experience, but it will still feel rewarding and thrilling to pass the toughest tests.

Overall rating... 10/10, would race again.

reviewText: Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed (SART) is a sequel to Sonic & Sega All-Stars Racing (SSAR), an arcade kart racing game that includes many characters and tracks from Sega titles, this one made by Sumo and released on PC in 2013. So yep, racing around competively, drifting and picking up random weapons to use on opponents.\nIt also got Xbox 360, PS3, WiiU, PSVita and 3DS versions as far as I am aware. And PC version actually got a bunch of exclusive characters (and exclusive DLC), like General Winter. Other versions weren't strangers to cameos from non-Sega franchises either. Though the only ones you miss are Avatar-using racers from Xbox 360 and WiiU. So be happy, you probably got the best version.\nIt also had a bonus edition" version for consoles which included Metal Sonic

reviewText:
Definitely one of the most amusing and amazing racing games I have seen in some time.

Playing as one of many SEGA characters (or guests such as the TF2 Crew and Ralph), you take to a highly detailed and very fluid racetrack and race your opponents to the finish. The tracks transform and give way to water or open skies, and your vehicle will transform between car/boat/plane to adjust to the changes.

I would say the positive points of this game come from the smoothness of the racing experience, and the rewarding feeling that comes from mastering a race course or passing a particular challenge. The campaign mode tests your abilities in race types varying from normal Races to Drift Challenges, Traffic Attacks to Tank Pursuits. Each racer may earn experience/levels, which lets you modify a racer to specialize in Speed, Acceleration, Handling, Boost, or a well-Balanced version of the stats they would normally use.

The only drawbacks: the difficulty curve rises sharply for each new difficulty level, and the AI-controlled racers don't mess around at all, especially on Hard/Expert difficulty; it may be a rough ride regardless of player experience, but it will still feel rewarding and thrilling to pass the toughest tests.

Overall rating... 10/10, would race again.

reviewText:
Love this game... My wife and I race each other each night (she usually kicks my butt) on the PS3 - we love playing battle race mode against each other.

The Steam PC version has even more racers. Works absolutely perfectly with my XBox 360 controller hooked up.

Multiple race modes, about 20 great tracks [huge variety + additional mirrored tracks can be unlocked too]. Very fast paced, and nice long tracks. Big variety of land/sea/air areas on most of the tracks, and some laps will change path patterns so it keeps you on your toes.

It may be an older game, but it's still one of my favorites. Love the variety of race characters that span across so many games. I highly recommend Sonic Transformed All Star Racing for anyone looking for some comical fun racing, either single or multiplayer. Definite thumbs up! :o)

reviewText:
Nice arcade racing game. Kinda reminds me of Asphalt 8 from iOS (stars for race completion, arcade drifting, boosters), but maybe all the arcade racings are like this, I haven't played them much.
Played it on free weekend, maybe i'll buy it before the sale ends. Wouldn't buy it without the discount, though. The game is still repetitive and has primitive gameplay mechanics.
I liked the leveldesign - bright, colorful and sort of psychedelic, loved the music and the character selection.
Decent console port, except they haven't drawn the graphics for keyboard keys, so the key pictures in gameplay tips are still from the XBOX gamepad. You'll have to peek in configuration utility to see what keys you need to use.
So pros - the game has nice look and feel, decent port from the console; cons - it's still simple arcade racing without any extra features (except for vehicle transformation, still not enough).
I'll give it 7/10.

reviewText:
Why is this so fun? This game should have no right to be this fun. There is list of things in this game that should automatically make it not so fun and enjoyable.

1: It's a sonic game
2: It's made by SEGA
3: It's a sonic game that has characters in it other than Sonic.
4: It is made by SEGA
5: It's a modern Sonic game made by SEGA
6: It's a blatent Mario-Kart clone

All those things combined should make it the worst game that SEGA has ever produced, but it's not. It's actually extremely fun and addictive like classic Mario Kart games were, the visuals and track designs are gorgeous in detail and faithfulness to all the classic SEGA franchises, especially the after burner stage with the remix of it's godlike stage theme.

I cant believe I'm saying this, but All Stars racing is definitely a game worth buying no matter the price, it's a Kart racing game done right.

reviewText:
AUDIO: Amazing                                               AESTHETIC: Fun
MEMORABILITY: Reasonable                          WORTH: Full Price

PROS: Absolute blast to play multiplayer. Lots of characters to choose from, all balanced with extra mod options. Gameplay is everything Mario Kart should be but hasn't had the guts to experiment with. Characters are all lively. Cups and ghosts are challenging and add plenty of lifespan to overall hours.

CONS: Some maps have a few consistently-glitchy spots. Water sections of stages are very hard to control, as well as drifting in plane-mode. Unlocking characters can be tedious. Half the unlockable tracks are just mirrored versions of preexisting ones.

OVERALL: An entertaining and controller-friendly racing game to be shared with friends. It may not satisfy the hardcore racer crowd, but it makes for a fun party game to put on with company.

SCORE: 10/10

reviewText:
Suppose i'll be the first to review in the open, i'm going to be a sport and say 4/5.

It's a well presented game that is really well optimised.

Real go getter for avid sonic fans, the soundtracks are very true so sonic of our spined friend's original days.

Controls are a breeze, lovely colourful backgrounds and variation in gameplay that will keep you on you're toes, there's unlockables and achievements to be had based on player skill and lots of challenges for the player to attempt, a large selection of alternative game modes and above all else, it's fun.

If you buy this one, i would have to say that if you don't quite get onboard with being hit with a rocket when you're in the lead, might be best going for another one, but as far as competive racing games go, i like it.

Graphics : 4/5

Great designs on maps although, visually nice to see, however, the wave textures are a little sloppy and at times they can interfere with control, though this is something that isn't that much of a problem.

Sound : 4/5

Decent, stereo sound tracks that display a little creativity on some original work of the previous sonic games, voice cast is those of familiar faces.

Gameplay : 3/5

Only discernable letdown is that there isn't an option for online grad prix modes, though there is plenty of room for exploration and a mountain of power-ups to gain the upper hand in races, help text is also shown between loading screens that will inform newcomers to a set weapon's function, over all a decently balanced expierience.

reviewText:
If I had to rate this game out of 5 I would give it a 3.

The game is really fun! You can transform into multiple vehicles, do challenging missions to improve upon your driving skills, and face other people to see whos better. The items can be annoying, but its sooooooo easy to climb back to 1st place if you know what your doing.

Though this game requires some skill, its fairly easy for any newcomers who just want to race and throw items at eachother.

The only downside is how glitchy the game is. Half the time when im in the top 3, I get easily knocked back to 10th thanks to flying in the sky for 30 secs, my car suddenly going the opposite direction and forcing myself to look the right direction, and just glitching through things in general.

I have played with atleast 6 friends whom i gifted to and usually one of them complains why they're glitched inside a rock or something similar.

reviewText:
This game is fun as hell, has astonishing graphics, cool music and great environments. Play it with friends or single-player, it's a unique experience.
BEWARE: it's ADDICTIVE AS HELL.
You may ask: How come?
Well let me tell you this: yesterday was GTA V's release and I got it for PS3. It's installed and I played 1-2 hours (don't get me wrong, I love the new GTA V and I think it's pure awesomeness... but ... but this little...) and in Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed I already have 9.2 hours of gameplay (single-player & multi-player).
THIS LITTLE GAME HAS THE POWER TO PUT GTA V ON HOLD - for that and not only for that I'll give it a 10/10 for the best arcade-racing game of 2013.
GORGEOUS!

reviewText: If you liked Diddy Kong Racing and also a challenge; then this is a title to pick up. The level designs are unique and well made. The single player is difficult but not too difficult once you learn how to perform tricks, transformation boosts, and starting boosts. Tons of characters to play around with and lots of achievements to collect throughout.

reviewText:
Excellent fast paced Kart racer as good as if not better than previous Mario Kart installments.
It will have you travelling by boat, cart and planes much like Diddy Kong Racing.

It has a pretty loyal Multiplayer community even though not very large.
There's a lot of fun packaged in this game with unlockable characters, vehicle mods, cups, time trials and a selection of multiplayer modes.

The visuals are lush and colorful even though not the most advanced they serve their purpose.
Audio design is overall great with some themed classic tunes blasting when a character gain power ups.

A must have for any fan of the genre.

reviewText:
Cause Driving A Kart Wasnt Hard Enough As Is...
Game Mechanics - 2/2
Story-line - 1/2
Graphics - 1.5/2
Soundtrack - 1.5/2
Replay Value - 2/2


Total Score - 8/10


So here I find myself writing up another Friday review for some faithful, interested gamer out there and I wouldn't have it any other way. With that said welcome to another Friday video game review here on In The Mind Of My Mind with your friendly neighborhood gamer Zalgo_Cometh. I been waiting and wanting to get myself a copy of this game from I heard they were making a part two after all the success the first game received. We reviewed Sonic & Sega All Star Racing two years ago and now its back for round two.Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is a racing video game developed by Sumo Digital and published by Sega. Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is the sequel to Sonic & Sega All-Stars Racing, the fourth installment in the Sega Superstars series, and the eighth racing game in the Sonic the Hedgehog series. Do you think the sequel lives up to its predecessor  Let's find out on today's exciting episode of Dragonball Z..........wait wrong show; I mean on today's blog review.



Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is a mascot-based racing game in which players race against each other using characters from various Sega franchises, although it features many new mechanics and improvements from the last game. The most obvious is that, at certain points in a race, vehicles can alternate between car, boat and plane modes. The car mode handles similarly to the previous game, in which players can earn boost by drifting around corners or performing tricks whilst in the air. Boat mode features true boating physics, requiring players to consider their vehicle's turbulence. They may also be affected by waves made in the water, some of which can be used to leap into the air and perform stunts. Plane mode, the fastest of the three forms, gives players the freedom to move both vertically and horizontally. Like the other modes, players can 'air-drift' around corners to earn boost and can also perform rolls to quickly adjust their position, earning boost for narrowly dodging obstacles. Players alternate between these modes by driving through blue transformation gates. Certain tracks in the game terraform as players proceed through them, offering different play-styles between each lap.



What’s Good:
Game-play: I must say Sega really listened to the fans and went all out to improve this series and I certainly see it as a worthy competitor to the Mario Kart franchise. With a wide variety of tweaks and subtle game-play enhancements this game certainly has quite the competitive edge to offer. When playing this game it certainly feels like a true race that is determined mostly by skill and not just sheer luck. From the changing track layout to the varying modes of transportation to the subtle handling differences in the varying modes of transport; Sega has offered up a selection of any and everything imaginable to affect a racing game of this wacky and nostalgic nature. Add into that the wide character roster of old and new faces alike and you simply cannot go wrong.

Replay Value:
With such a wide cast of characters to explore how could you not have replay value? Add to that a variety of race modes and tracks for both single player and multi-player enjoyment and you will be begging for a break. Sega went even further and gave us a leveling system for each character and different car mods to unlock and explore for each of your favorite characters. This is what you call some serious replay value.


What’s Bad:
Story-line: WHERE IS THE STORY LINE? WHY DO I NOT KNOW HOW THESE CHARACTERS ALL GOT TO THIS DIMENSION? WHAT ARE THEY EVEN RACING FOR? Hell the most important question of them all is why Sonic is even driving a car when he is obviously the fastest participant of this whole racing game? Trolling aside it would have been nice to have a dedicated story-line to help add value to the game and develop more interest in the varying characters.


What Should Have Been Added:
Pretty much like I said that only main thing I would have wanted to see was a properly fleshed out story to help solidify this game.


Final Thoughts:
I am definitely glad to see the success this game is receiving and hope that Sega and Sumo Digital continue to make this a worthy addition to the kart racing game genre. especially since its the only kart racing game I know of that has a version for PC which is way easier to get people to play on locally than with a handheld or a console. I hope to see continued variety of character inclusion from the illustrious Sega collection of characters they have at their disposal.

This game is great fun and probably the most fun I've had with a kart racer since Mario Kart DS. There's  a nice assortment of characters (maybe too much from Sonic), a lot of levels which are pretty much all fantastic (with mirror versions), and the controls are tight. While it's a kart racer, skill plays a large factor and items can only do so much when going up against skilled opponents. My main gripe is that there are some issues which can occur with collision on the tracks, specifically with regards to skyboxes, but these hardly detract from the overall experience and occur infrequently. The graphics are nice, the music is great, and the game just plays very well. This is a great game and I recommend this to anyone interested in racing games or with a love for Sega.

A solid, gorgeous kart racer where the speed is palpable in comparison to others. The AI is challenging (Although it feels like it cheats at times). The course design is variety of well-made circuits inspired by SEGA properties. This is a good value at any price, and is frequently on sale.

As Sonic and Sega All-Stars second outing into the Kart racing arena, Sumo Digital have modified the formulae through introducing transforming vehicles.
With a larger roster of playable characters from some of the companies most beloved franchises and corresponding courses, hectic split-screen and online competition ensues.
Some of Sonic's 3D adventures have not quite reached terminal velocity, but with the help of the Sega stable, does his kart caper steal the limelight from a certain Italian plumber.

Featuring a breadth of single and multiplayer modes. The World Tour mode acts as an introduction to both the game mechanics and further game modes. These include time attack, battle race, traffic attack and boost races with inventive timed challenges.

Each lap features dynamic tracks with land, sea and air obstacles. The players vehicle teraforms accordingly within each zone requiring a unique strategy to control the vehicle. With multiple routes through each course, it pays to experiment and fine tune your approach.
A key tactic is maintaining a 'boost' via boosting pads and rings, landing a series of tricks or drifting. Its easily achieved with the brake input and long sharp turns can be mastered to achieve a level 3 boost.

As you progress through the tour you unlock up to 3 medals per event based on your difficulty chose, which are then used to unlock new events and characters. The game also features a traditional Grand Prix, with playlists of all the races found in the world tour.

The game revives a wealth of characters from throughout Sega's history, re-imagining them in slick, new HD forms. There's also plenty of fan service in the form of the fantastically inventive tracks and items that are all uniquely helpful, whilst never becoming unfair game changers.

The mechanic of transforming throughout a race works extremely well, forcing the player to adapt their play style completely. Whilst giving accurate feedback and control from the sky and waves, rather than being a mere automated aesthetic change.

Although racing is a well polished mechanic and revisited throughout the various modes – it is easily re-playable both on your own and with others.
Furthermore the invention of boost races and traffic attacks are entertaining but also serve to test and improve your specific abilities in boosting and navigating a course. The game can be both very accessible and challenging, but these are fair frustrations which ultimately make you a better player.

With over 25 playable characters, there are a range of vehicles with different perks to conquer different challenges. Although there are none to detest some are licensed characters making an unusual appearance.
Each character can also level up with races earning them modifiers to improve or balance each attribute of their vehicle. Rather than being a player license level it requires each character to be levelled up, ultimately for the same items and begins to feel like an RPG grind.

Sega have raided their treasure troves to craft a balance kart racer, that makes innovative strides in the genre. Not only does it look great and play well, but it reinstates some of its greatest veterans in reminiscent worlds.
Sumo Digital have refined the kart racing genre in their offering whilst introducing a more dynamic take of plane and boat racing with sophisticated environmental physics. The game manages to capture what was great and good about Sega whilst becoming an exceptional addition to their roster. Perhaps Sonic is faster behind the wheel.

Watch at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3tTUg00HeyY&list=UUxz-iPSjsZAsGhFY7zLfi9g

One of the best kart racers I've played. The racing feels great - you get an incredible sense of speed when riding around on the well-designed tracks...something that feels right at home in a Sonic title. The items and racing require quite a bit of skill, making for some fun, intense matches. The game looks beautiful and there is a lot of excellent music in the game.\n\nThere are a few reasons that this fall short of my favorite kart racer, Diddy Kong Racing. DKR was wonderful in that it had an open world to explore along with an actual actual story mode. Kart racers that don't include these things always seem a little flat to me, Racing Transformed not being an exception. Still, it's one of the best kart racers money can buy, and it can be bought for $5 on PC fairly regularly. Definitely recommended.

One of the best Mario Kart clones out there, and an excellent PC port. Looks and runs perfectly. If you were a Sega kid, you'll love the impressive amount of fan-service here. I had a lot of fun with the prior game in this series as well. The air and sea gameplay here is often more frustrating than fun, but it's tolerable. If you would prefer things to be cart-only, then just stick with the prior game, unless you can nab this for $5 or so. I didn't play the online multiplayer, so I can't comment on that.

Easily the best kart racer of this generation, and probably the best one ever released on PC. It's not a dramatic departure from the formula invented by Mario Kart, but Sonic Transformed tweaks and improves upon that formula in a lot of ways that make it even better than Nintendo's more recent offerings. Weapons are a lot more fair and can be dodged with quick and careful driving. The single-player mode offers up a huge amount of missions with a lot of variety. The graphics are gorgeous. The trick system for earning boosts encourages learning the tracks. The three different vehicle modes all handle very differently. There's a lot of depth here if you want to dive into the time trials.

And if you're into Sega, this has a ridiculous amount of fanservice. From Segata Sanshiro to Burning Rangers to Panzer Dragoon, this is the ultimate tribute to Sega's history.

About the only major flaw is the inability to turn off weapons in online or grand prix play. Some of the single-player missions are weaponless races, and it's a real shame that you can't play like that with friends or in a racing series. But it's telling that I consider that a flaw - that the core racing in a kart racer is so good that I want to enjoy it without the accoutrements normally layered on top of games in the genre.

Buy it, buy it now.

If you like arcade racers, this is the best modern one. Its been out for  a couple years now, but is better than all the new stuff.  I got a WiiU for mariokart 8, and wow that was a waste. Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed is a lot of fun and really improves on its predecessor. The gameplay is smooth and responsive and the races feel action packed. There is a large variety of weapons to thwart your competition and a good variety of brilliantly designed courses. The courses never get boring because a number of them alternate between being ground based, water based and aviation based depending on the lap or course you are on. Different characters start off with and transform into different vehicles suited to the type of race. Each individual character also earns different 'mods' for their vehicles when they level up which alter their stats.\nThe announcer from the previous game is no longer in it and instead it is just spectated when you are owning the race" or have performed a stunt or attack. The soundtrack is as good and as fitting  as ever with some really well done remixes. You can play with up to four players but playing against the AI also offers up a worthy challenge depending on the chosen difficulty. Playing on a higher difficulty rewards you with more stars which are used to unlock more characters
date: courses and bonuses.\nThe are only two things that grate on me about this game
recommended: one being the inclusion of characters that just don't seem to fit such as 'Danica Patrick' who appeared in the game because she was sponsored by Sega. In my opinion it would have been better to include some more well known characters such as Kazuma from the Yakuza series which was by Sega. On the upside there were a few DLC characters that were added for free.\nThe final annoyance is that I have found the game sometimes crashes to desktop for no apparent reason. This is no reason to not buy the game (because it is a justified purchase that offers a shed load of fun) but it can induce some serious rage when you're in the middle of a race or have just set up a multiplayer session."

reviewText: Good graphics for a not so recent game, nice controls with controller, very fun to play!

Fantastic game for fans of kart racers. It has quite a high learning curve and is deceptively difficult so don't go into this thinking this will be an easy game. Don't let that put you off though as it is very rewarding improving your racing skills.

Every vehicle feels different. I tried getting a couple of my friends who are huge Mario Kart fans to play. They liked the feel of the cars but not of the other vehicles due to unfamiliarity. If you're not willing to give the game a chance due to reasons like that then you won't enjoy it. Stick with it though and you will find a beautiful, and enjoyable racing game and the best alternative to Mario Kart that you will find.

The netcode has some problems which does lower enjoyment somewhat but the online matches are still the most enjoyable part of the game. Racing against other players is way more fun than racing the computer.

Dare I say that if the game was more polished it may have even taken the Mario Kart crown!

Highly recommended!

Don't let the title character scare you off. This game is easily among the best mascot racing titles available, and holds its own next to the likes of Mario Kart. It's relatively easy to pick up but insanely difficult to master, and you'll sink many hours into getting just one more star. Not many games nowadays support couch multiplayer either, and this is one that does it elegantly and provides a very fun time in the process.\n\nWith 42 possible tracks (20 normal, 20 mirrored and 2 bonus tracks), a truckload of characters (some specific to the PC release) and many goals and achievements to earn, you'll easily be at this one for a long time.

If it was worth me buying a second copy, as I already own a near-fully completed copy on my PS3, then that certainly states that I recommend this game to not only Sonic and SEGA fans, but fans of racing games and videogames in general.

If you want more graphical charm and don't have an amazing PC (like me) you may be better off getting a console version, but seriously, buy this amazing gem of a racer right now! It is worth MORE than the pricetag of $20, and certainly more than the $5 that it is on sale for!

reviewText: I guess i should start with being honest, i am bias towards racing games as they made up a great portion of my childhood gaming experience, having grown up with games like: Crash Team Racing, Gran Turismo, Mario Kart, Ridge Racer, Toy Story Racing, and so on; although often the crucible of frustration and anger but still very dear to me. After playing 'Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed' i can wholeheartedly say without a doubt that this racing games takes the cake as the most enjoyable for me. Naturally this is my own, personal opinion and i'm aware that others will disagree, but i think that this particular racing game is just brilliant; great characters, courses, stunts, boosts, challenges, soundtrack, online playability, you name it and it's here.\n\nAny racing lover needs to try this game, you won't be disappointed.

reviewText: good, glitchy but good

What at first seems like a poor man's Mario Kart turns out to be one of the largest, most polished, and, most importantly, balanced, kart racers ever made. There's no rubber band AI or Blue Shells here, the majority of races are won with one thing and one thing alone: skill. Sure, items can help or hinder your position, but they'll never be a complete game changer. Topped off with gorgeous courses, a soundtrack composed of both original pieces and remixed ones, and plenty of content, All-Stars Racing Transformed is incredibly fun and sure to keep you racing.
Firstly, it inspires optimism to know that Sega still knows how to make its AAA stuff all videogamey."\n\nSecondly

Where Sonic & Sega All-Stars Racing was a fun, casual Mario Kart knock off, this latest installment to Sega racing has been transformed (ho ho) into a fairly unique and challenging experience.  Well, as unique as Sega gets these days.  Fun racings.

Scale: 1=despised 2=negative 3=could go either way 4=acceptable 5=loved
Game design: 4/5  Controls and graphics have been tightened up a lot since the last game, and I didn't think anything was wrong with them then.  I'm not paying attention to the music nearly as much, but that isn't a bad thing.
Tone: 4/5  Not nearly as light hearted as the last game, but that suits the changes perfectly.
Personal skew: 3/5  Meh.  Sega promotes both aspiration and fear in my heart.

A lot of people think this game is just a copy of Mario Kart 7, due to the flying and boat transformations. However, alot of people don't know that Sega had the Idea first. I bought the original game on my DS. Not very good graphics or gameplay. Then I saw this game on sale, and I couldn't stop myself from buying it, as well as a little bit of DLC. This game is amazing. 10/10. The graphics have improved, though that may just be my opinion because of the DS' graphics. The gameplay is better than Mario Kart. In Mario Kart 7, during the flying sections, you don't feel much control. Sonic & All-Stars Racing: Transformed fixes that. At first I didn't realize I had much power over flying, so I ended up in last place. I even had the game turn on Y-axis. Also the game's cast of characters are great. Wreck It Ralph, Yogscast, Pyro, Heavy, and Spy all make appearances. Well, Pyro, Heavy, and Spy make up one team called Team Fortess, so, does that still count? I'm saying yes. Anyways, if this game wasn't on sale I probably wouldn't even try it. But, I ended up loving it. Man, I love this game.\n
Worth every penny! mad fun to play.  buy it!

When you first look at Sonic all stars racing transformed, it seems like nothing more than a generic kart racer staring sonic.  However if you dig deep enough you'll find a much more complex racing system than in most other racing game.  First of all in addition to the karts you also have access to boats and planes for all characters.  This is where the games design shines as often you'll get multiple options of where to go, one where you take the high road in the skies and the other plodding on the ground or in a boat.  Another nice thing is the items which are only there to spice the game up rather than giving sucky players an unfair advantage.  Even the all star move is balanced in a way that it only really helps if you know how to use it.  The game looks amazing when running at max settings though I've noticed some significant issues with fps even when at minimal settings(Though this may just be my computer.  The game does have it's flaws, characters aren't varried that much especially since all star moves are so much more bland compared to the first game, and the leveling up system is dull and tedious beyond words.  Also I highly reccomend you play this using a controller only as playing with the mouse and keyboard sucks so much its not even worth trying.  But this is the definitive version of All stars transformed as it has additional characters with more promised while the console ports are left in the dust.  And since this game has gone on sale a couple of times since it's release there's little excuse not to pick it up.

I don't know who'd not buy the game. It's amazing. And of course, has Sonic and all of your favorite characters!


GENERAL:
Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed gives you 3 ways to play; alone, with people from all around the world, and at private party. And there's even more ways to play when you play solo. Giving you alot of hours to play for your amusement!


CONTENT:
You got 30+ characters in this platform. Yes, 30 characters, including the DLC and the unlockable characters from your favorite titles: Sonic, Super Monkey Ball, and so much more! And you can play with them on over 40 tracks. That's alot of combinations there. And it dosen't stop there, you get 5 gamemodes to play with, the combinations are HUGE here.

GAMEPLAY:
The gameplay is divine. It's like SEGA learned from it's mistakes from SEGA All Stars Racing ancestor and remade it into a more original creation. It's nothing like Mario Kart at all, where you must get OP items to win. If you play alone, you can progress through the game, collect and upgrade your characters! And some singleplayer portions are difficult. It's mechanics are also great. Don't like playing alone? Play online and show the world what you're made of!



WEAKNESSES AND CONCERNS:
There are problems with this game though, no matter how good it is. First being is that to win, you have to rely on one mechanic: Powerful boostings at a rapid rate. You'll never have a decent Time Attack record without a powerful character. I.E. Shadow with Dreamcast mod is one of them. But if you're skilled, you shouldn't have alot of problems with that.
Another concern about this is the server. Though the community is friendly, the servers you're gonna play in, will never be. As you're mixed with these new guys, and real MLG players, and some of them may have bad connection, causing an unbearable amount of crashing into walls and such. Even MLG players suffer from that.
Yet another concern is the aftermath, and I mean what happens now when you beat the game, although I like this game, I, at one point, abandoned it because of how usual it is. But I returned to it in a few months after.
One of my worries are also being about the tracks, although there's 42 tracks at most, the other 21 is  just mirrored.
Last one is about one of the mechanics: The Casino. Chances are in a race, you could get a crappy thing, but a really good one is actually rare. I.E. The useless Nitro is often, but the best ones, like Titanium Frame or Stunt Nitro is almost impossible.


FINAL THOUGHTS:
To be honest, I love the game, it has alot of potential. But I wish that the developers could realise it. But then again, they might be working on something that could beat this. You should get it at full price, but if you take the problems seriously, then maybe at 20-40% off. I give it a 8.9/10

It's Sega's version of Mario Kart.  Or maybe Diddy Kong Racing since you transform on the fly mid-race on a regular basis.  You'll see levels derived from such Sega classics as Nights, Golden Axe, After Burner, House of the Dead, Billy Hatcher, Super Monkey Ball, Samba de Amigo, Skies of Arcadia, Jet Grind Radio, and much more.  And you get to play as characters from all of those games and more.\n\nThis is a huge love letter from Sega wrapped in race tracks and you owe it to yourself to pick this up if you haven't already.

Don't let the title character scare you off. This game is easily among the best mascot racing titles available, and holds its own next to the likes of Mario Kart. It's relatively easy to pick up but insanely difficult to master, and you'll sink many hours into getting just one more star. Not many games nowadays support couch multiplayer either, and this is one that does it elegantly and provides a very fun time in the process.\n\nWith 42 possible tracks (20 normal, 20 mirrored and 2 bonus tracks), a truckload of characters (some specific to the PC release) and many goals and achievements to earn, you'll easily be at this one for a long time.

[h] Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed: Surprisingly Good [/h]

Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed (hereafter referred to as Sonic Racing), is a very weel designed kart racing game. It takes aspects from games like Mario Kart and improves on them, and is arguably better than Mario Kart. Althoug it's not a perfect port, it is still a nice game.

Pros:
-One of few kart racers for PC, with splitscreen
-Racing is smooth and well-designed
-A whole bunch of characters from all over the place
-Plays moderatly well with a keyboard
-Plays great with controller

Cons:
-Some issues with the port (lag during loadtimes, took some tweaking to get it working on a tv)
-Connecting additional controllers took a bit of work

All in all, I think Sonic Racing is a fun party game to throw on if you have some controllers and some friends.

The frankly bizarre roster is likely to inspire a love or hate response, featuring distinctly non-iconic characters like Wreck-It Ralph, Football Manager and real-life driver Danica Patrick, but past that is a genuinely fantastic kart racer with a lot of care put into its design.

I was intensely skeptical at first, but Sumo Digital have put together a genuine competitor to Mario Kart, and a distinctly less luck-based one at that. The branching track design and stackable" boost system both contribute to making the game easy to pick up while also ensuring that victory in higher-level matches is very much a matter of skill.

The game comes with a comprehensive host of local and online multiplayer options as well as a fairly substantial singleplayer campaign. Highly recommended."

Fantastic game for fans of kart racers. It has quite a high learning curve and is deceptively difficult so don't go into this thinking this will be an easy game. Don't let that put you off though as it is very rewarding improving your racing skills.

Every vehicle feels different. I tried getting a couple of my friends who are huge Mario Kart fans to play. They liked the feel of the cars but not of the other vehicles due to unfamiliarity. If you're not willing to give the game a chance due to reasons like that then you won't enjoy it. Stick with it though and you will find a beautiful, and enjoyable racing game and the best alternative to Mario Kart that you will find.

The netcode has some problems which does lower enjoyment somewhat but the online matches are still the most enjoyable part of the game. Racing against other players is way more fun than racing the computer.

Dare I say that if the game was more polished it may have even taken the Mario Kart crown!

Highly recommended!
